Detailed Description

This is the main source code for the kernel.

Here all important variables will be initialized.

Definition in file kernel.c.

Function Documentation

static int allocate_thread ( void   )  [inline, static]

Allocate one thread.

The allocated thread is not initialized. Rip and rflags need to be set for the thread to start properly.

Returns:
An index into thread_table or -1 if no thread could be allocated.

00364        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG2] != 'L') ||

00366        /* Check that the image is a 64-bit image. */
00367        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_CLASS] != 2) ||
00368        /* Check that the image is a little endian image. */
00369        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_DATA] != 1) ||
00370        /* And that the version of the image format is correct. */
00371        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_VERSION] != 1) ||
00372        /* NB: We do not check the ABI or ABI version. We really should
00373           but currently those fields are not set properly by the build
00374           tools. They are both set to zero which means: System V ABI,
00375           third edition. However, the ABI used is clearly not System V :-) */
00376 
00377        /* Check that the image is executable. */
00378        (image->elf_image.e_type != 2) ||
00379        /* Check that the image is executable on AMD64. */
00380        (image->elf_image.e_machine != 0x3e) ||
00381        /* Check that the object format is corrent. */
00382        (image->elf_image.e_version != 1) ||
00383        /* Check that the processor dependent flags are all reset. */
00384        (image->elf_image.e_flags != 0) ||

00390        /* Check that the number of entries is reasonable. */

00392        (image->elf_image.e_phnum > 8) ||

00394        (image->elf_image.e_entry < 0) ||
00395        (image->elf_image.e_entry >= image_size) ||

00400       )

00402    {

00407     }

00433           (((program_header[program_header_index].p_flags & ~7) != 0) ||

00455         address 0. Also, calculate the memory footprint of the image. */

00476    executable_table_size += 1;
00477 
00478    kprints("Found an executable image.\n");
00479 
00480    if (executable_table_size >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00481    {

00490  /* Check that actually some executable files are found. Also check that the

00493     protection in task A4. */

00495  if ((0 >= executable_table_size) ||

00507  /* All sub-systems are now initialized. Kernel areas can now get the right
00508     memory protection. */

00512   struct Elf32_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf32_Phdr*)

00535  /* Start running the first program in the executable table. */
00536 
00537  /* Use the ELF program header table and copy the right portions of the
00538     image to memory. This is done by prepare_process. */
00539 
00540  {
00541   struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process_ret_val = 
00542    prepare_process(executable_table[0].elf_image,
00543                    0,

00545 
00546   if (0 == prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address)

00550     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not start process 0!\n");
00551    }

00554   /* Start executable program 0 as process 0. At this point, there are no
00555      processes so we can just grab entry 0 and use it. */
00556   process_table[0].parent=-1;    /* We put -1 to indicate that there is no
00557                                     parent process. */
00558   process_table[0].threads=1;
00559   
00560   /*  all processes should start with an allocated port with id zero */
00561   if (-1 == allocate_port(0,0))
00562   {

00564    {
00565     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not initialize the IPC system!\n");
00566    }

00569   /* Set the page table address. */
00570   process_table[0].page_table_root =
00571    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00572   cpu_private_data.page_table_root =
00573    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00574 
00575   /* We need a thread. We just take the first one as no threads are running or
00576      have been allocated at this point. */
00577   thread_table[0].data.owner=0;  /* 0 is the index of the first process. */
00578 
00579   /* We reset all flags and enable interrupts */
00580   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rflags=0x200;
00581 
00582   /* And set the start address. */
00583   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rip =
00584    prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address;
00585 
00586   /* Finally we set the current thread. */
00587   cpu_private_data.thread_index = 0;
00588  }
00589 
00590  /* Set up the timer hardware to generate interrupts 200 times a second. */
00591  outb(0x43, 0x36);
00592  outb(0x40, 78);
00593  outb(0x40, 23);
00594 
00595  /* Now we set up the interrupt controller to allow timer interrupts. */
00596  outb(0x20, 0x11);
00597  outb(0xA0, 0x11);
00598 
00599  outb(0x21, 0x20);
00600  outb(0xA1, 0x28);
00601 
00602  outb(0x21, 1<<2);
00603  outb(0xA1, 2);
00604 
00605  outb(0x21, 1);
00606  outb(0xA1, 1);
00607

00609  outb(0xA1, 0xff);
00610 
00611  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00612  /* Now go back to the assembly language code and let the process run. */
00613 }

00086 {
00087  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00088  register int      i;
00089 
00090  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00091     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00092     of the number of source code lines. */
00093  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00094  {
00095   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00096  }
00097 }

static struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process ( const struct Elf64_Ehdr *  elf_image,
const unsigned int  process,
unsigned long  memory_footprint_size 
) [static, read]

Copies an ELF image to memory and prepares a process.

prepare_process does some checks to avoid that corrupt images gets copied to memory. However, the checks are not as thorough as the check in initialize.

Returns:
A prepare_process_return_value struct holding the first address of the process image and an address to the page table for the process.
Parameters:
elf_image  Points to the ELF image to copy.
process  The index of the process that is to be created.
memory_footprint_size  Holds the maximum amount of memory, in bytes, the image is allowed to use.

00183  /* Update the start of the block to be after the page table. */
00184 
00185  address_to_memory_block += 19*4*1024;
00186 
00187  /* Scan through the program header table and copy all PT_LOAD segments to
00188     memory. Perform checks at the same time.*/
00189 
00190  for (program_header_index = 0;
00191       program_header_index < elf_image->e_phnum;
00192       program_header_index++)
00193  {
00194   if (PT_LOAD == program_header[program_header_index].p_type)
00195   {
00196    /* Calculate destination adress. */
00197    unsigned long* dst = (unsigned long *) (address_to_memory_block + 
00198                                            used_memory);
00199 
00200    /* Check for odd things. */
00201    if (
00202        /* Check if the segment is contiguous */
00203        (used_memory != program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr) ||
00204        /* Check if the segmen fits in memory. */
00205        (used_memory + program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz >
00206         memory_footprint_size) ||
00207        /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the segment
00208           size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00209        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00210        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)))
00211    {
00212     /* Something went wrong. Panic. */
00213     while(1)
00214     {
00215      kprints(
00216 "Kernel panic: Trying to create a process out of a corrupt executable image!");
00217     }
00218    }
00219 
00220    /* First copy p_filesz from the image to memory. */
00221    {
00222     /* Calculate the source address. */
00223     unsigned long* src = (unsigned long *) (((char*) elf_image)+
00224      program_header[program_header_index].p_offset);
00225     unsigned long count = program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz/8;
00226 
00227     for(; count>0; count--)
00228     {
00229      *dst++=*src++;
00230     }
00231    }
00232 
00233 
00234    /* Then write p_memsz-p_filesz bytes of zeros. This to pad the segment. */
00235    {
00236     unsigned long count = (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz-
00237                            program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz)/8;
00238 
00239     for(; count>0; count--)
00240     {
00241      *dst++=0;
00242     }
00243    }
00244 
00245    /* Set the permission bits on the loaded segment. */
00246    update_memory_protection(ret_val.page_table_address,
00247                             program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr+
00248                              address_to_memory_block,
00249                             program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz,
00250                             program_header[program_header_index].p_flags&7);
00251 
00252    /* Finally update the amount of used memory. */
00253    used_memory += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00254   }
00255  }
00256 
00257  /* Find out the address to the first instruction to be executed. */
00258  ret_val.first_instruction_address = address_to_memory_block +
00259                                      elf_image->e_entry;
00260 
00261  return ret_val;
00262 }

Variable Documentation

const char* const ELF_images_end

The address of the first byte after the end of the last ELF image.

This variable is used for sanity checking.

long system_time = 0

This variable holds the current system time.

The system time is the number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 17 of file kernel.c.

Referenced by allocate_thread(), initialize(), thread_queue_dequeue(), and thread_queue_enqueue().

int timer_queue_head = -1

The index, into thread_table, of the head of the timer queue.

The timer queue is a list of threads blocked waiting for the system clock to reach a certain time. This variable is set to -1 if there are no threads in the timer queue.
